Award.AwardTitle: SI2-SSI: Collaborative Research: A Robust High-Throughput Ab Initio Computation and Analysis Software Framework for Interface Materials Science

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
A set of techniques scientists call "ab initio" methods, which are derived from the fundamental laws of physics with minimal assumptions and approximations, has become a critical tool in the study and design of materials. With computing advances and software innovations, the automation of high-throughput ab initio calculations has, in particular, heralded an explosion of computed data for a large variety of materials. However, these high-throughput efforts are limited to specific properties. In contrast, materials interfaces, one of the fastest growing research areas in materials science and engineering, are showing an increasing relevance in many areas of materials applications such as catalysis and electronics. This project will develop a software framework that enables novel high-throughput interface materials investigations and design. The developed software platform will expand the genome of materials by including the computed interfacial properties of interface materials. This community-based software can potentially become a critical component of the Materials Genome Initiative and serve not just the large and diverse materials research community, but also the physics and chemistry communities. Besides featuring heavily in existing and planned courses taught by the Principal Investigators in their home institutions, the proposed framework will facilitate the training of undergraduates and graduates in the ab initio methodologies in other institutions as well. This project will also conduct public outreach activities to increase awareness of the importance of sustainable software development for data-driven interface materials science.

The project will develop necessary workflow management, error correction schemes, and systematic analysis tools to support ab initio studies of thermodynamics, kinetics, diffusion, and electronic property of interface materials including hetero-structures and grain boundary. It targets developmental efforts on three key focus areas of great interest to interface materials science: (i) ab initio thermodynamics of surfaces and interfaces; ii) advanced methods for materials kinetics and diffusion at materials interfaces; and iii) automated algorithms for structural construction of grain boundary and post data-processing and analysis. In doing so, this project will greatly expand the suite of interfacial materials properties that are amenable to a high-throughput ab initio treatment, paving the way for materials investigations and design in a broad spectrum of technological applications, including energy generation and storage, catalysis and electronics. In addition, by interfacing with classical-mechanics simulation codes, this framework will bridge the gap between the ab initio and classical force-field approach, which is expected to significantly advance the high-throughput simulations of materials interfaces.

This award by the Advanced Cyberinfrastructure Division is jointly supported by the NSF Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences (Division of Materials Research and Office of Multidisciplinary Activities).

POR.DRECONTENT:
Surfaces and interfaces are one of the fastest-growing areas of research in the fields of materials science and engineering. The materials properties of surfaces and interfaces are showing an increasing relevance in many areas of materials applications such as catalysis and electronics. One example is the recent discovery of two-dimensional electron gas at perovskite oxide interface, in which two band insulators combine together and forms highly conducting metallic states at the interface. Another example is the grain boundaries, a well-known plane defects in materials, which are one relatively simple but ubiquitous and technologically important interfaces. While advances are being made in the compositional-structural understanding of bulk material properties for these applications, the greatest unknown, and thus the greatest challenge, is the fundamental understanding of the material surfaces and interfaces such as the surface/interface structural reconstruction, interface ion diffusion, and electronic reconstruction. 

 Driven by the national materials genome initiative, tremendous efforts have been made to develop the quantum bulk materials repository such as the Materials Project and AFLOWLIB library. Nevertheless, most of these HT computational efforts today still primarily focus on the bulk materials for reasons of computational cost and complexity, and there are pressing needs for software that support ab initio investigations and calculations for materials surfaces and interfaces.

This project has produced several open-source software libraries and 24 peer-reviewed research articles. Several significant research outcomes are summarized as below:

  1. An algorithm implemented in an open-source python library was developed for building periodic grain boundary models in a universal fashion. The software framework aims to generate tilt and twist grain boundaries from an input cubic or non-cubic crystal structure for ab-initio and classical atomistic simulation. This framework has two useful features: (i) it can calculate all the CSL matrices for generating CSL from a given Sigma (Σ) value and rotation axis, allowing the users to build the specific CSL and grain boundary models; (ii) it provides a convenient command-line tool to enable the high-throughput generation of tilt and twist grain boundaries by assigning an input crystal structure, Σ value, rotation axis, and grain boundary plane. The developed algorithm in the open-source python library is able to facilitate studies of grain boundary in materials science and has become one critical component for the national materials genome initiative and data-driven materials science.  

  2. This project has yielded a series of fundamental knowledge on the materials interfaces, i.e., the relationship between the materials interface structures and interfacial energetic, electronic, and magnetic properties. Several significant results under this category are summarized as below: a) A systematic computational and theoretical studies of the perovskite oxide interfaces have revealed three different interfacial configurations and mechanisms to produce two-dimensional electron gas at the materials interfaces; b) The atomistic origin of the interfacial perpendicular magnetic anisotropy at the magnetic/oxides interface (MgO/Co2FeAl) was revealed and clarified and optimization approaches to further enhance the interfacial magnetic anisotropy in the MgO/Co2FeAl and MgO/Fe materials were proposed.

  3. This project has also yielded a fundamental understanding of the strain effects on the hybrid perovskites materials, and a high-throughput computational study has successfully identified a series of lead-free candidate hybrid materials for optoelectronic applications, including 23 candidates for light-emitting diodes and 13 candidates for solar energy conversion. This work demonstrates a new avenue to design novel organic-inorganic functional materials by exploring a great variety of prototype structures. This work also enabled a great expansion of materials classes with respect to the pure inorganic materials and organic molecules, extending the “genome” of materials into hybrid materials, in support of the national materials genome initiative. In particular, this research article was published in the most prestigious journal Energy and Environmental Science and has been widely reported in multiple media including XSEDE (“Supercomputers Help Engineers Discover New Materials for Solar Cells and LEDs”) and San Diego Computing Center (SDSC) (“Data Science Helps Engineers Discover New Materials for Solar Cells and LEDs -- SDSC’s ‘Comet’ Supercomputer Simulations Help Make Project Possible”), yielding broad impacts.

  4. This project also produced broader education impacts by broadening participation of underrepresented students through various types of research mentorship programs including the Faculty Mentor Program, the Center for Inclusion, Diversity, Excellence, and Advancement (IDEA Center) at the Jacobs School of Engineering and ENLACE bi-national summer research program at UC San Diego. This project has also trained new-generation computational materials scientists including Ph.D. and graduate students (four Ph.D. students have graduated and are currently working as postdoctoral researchers now). These students have been educated with state-of-the-art technical expertise and knowledge to apply and develop ab-initio computation methodologies.
